text:
The **economy of Liberia** is extremely underdeveloped, with only $3.222
billion by gross domestic product as of 2019, largely due to the First
(1989–1996) and Second Liberian Civil War (1999–2003). Liberia itself is one
of the poorest and least developed countries in the world, according to the
United Nations.

Until 1979, Liberia's economy was among the more developed and fastest-growing
in Sub-Saharan Africa, but after the 1980 coup d'état, it declined, and the
civil war destroyed much of Liberia's economy and infrastructure, especially
the infrastructure in and around the nation's capital, Monrovia. The war also
caused a brain drain and the loss of capital, as the civil war involved
overthrowing the Americo-Liberian minority that ruled the country. Some have
returned since 1997, but many have not.

Liberia is richly endowed with water, mineral resources, forests, and a
climate favorable to agriculture, but poor in human capital, infrastructure,
and stability. Liberia has a fairly typical profile for Sub-Saharan African
economies. The majority of the population is reliant on subsistence
agriculture, while exports are dominated by raw commodities such as rubber and
iron ore. Local manufacturing, such as it exists, is mainly foreign-owned.

The democratically elected government, installed in August 1997, inherited
massive international debts and currently relies on revenues from its maritime
registry to provide the bulk of its foreign exchange earnings. The restoration
of the infrastructure and the raising of incomes in this ravaged economy
depend on the implementation of sound macro- and microeconomic policies of the
new government, including the encouragement of foreign investment.[_according
to whom?_]
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Liberia is extremely underdeveloped, with a gross domestic product (GDP) of only $3.222 billion as of 2019, primarily due to the impacts of the First Liberian Civil War (1989–1996) and the Second Liberian Civil War (1999–2003).
• According to the United Nations, Liberia is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world.
• Prior to 1979, Liberia's economy was among the more developed and fastest-growing in Sub-Saharan Africa.

• The 1980 coup d'état precipitated a decline in Liberia’s economy, which was further devastated by the civil wars that destroyed much of the country's economy and infrastructure, especially in and around the capital city, Monrovia.

• The civil wars caused a significant brain drain and loss of capital, as the conflicts involved the overthrow of the Americo-Liberian minority that had ruled the country; although some expatriates returned after 1997, many did not.
• Liberia is richly endowed with natural resources, including abundant water, mineral resources, forests, and a climate favorable to agriculture.
• Despite these natural endowments, Liberia suffers from deficiencies in human capital, infrastructure, and political stability.
• Liberia’s economic profile is fairly typical of Sub-Saharan African economies, with the majority of the population dependent on subsistence agriculture.
• Liberia’s exports are dominated by raw commodities, notably rubber and iron ore.
• Local manufacturing in Liberia is limited and primarily foreign-owned.
• The democratically elected government installed in August 1997 inherited massive international debts.
• Liberia relies heavily on revenues from its maritime registry to provide the bulk of its foreign exchange earnings.

• The restoration of Liberia’s infrastructure and the improvement of incomes depend on the implementation of sound macroeconomic and microeconomic policies by the government, including the encouragement of foreign investment.

text:
Much of independent Liberia's economic history is subject to limited archival
documentation, making it hard for economic historians to make comprehensive
assessments about the nature of Liberia's economy over time. The Liberian
government only began producing GDP per capita data in 1964.

A 2022 study by LSE economic historian Leigh A. Gardner assessed that Liberian
GDP per capita was $430 in 1845, which was just above subsistence and
approximately half of Japan's GDP per capita at the time. It rose to
approximately $500 by the time of independence, but the economy subsequently
stagnated until the 1930s when a period of rapid economic growth began.
Whereas Liberia had been poorer than Ghana during the 19th and early 20th
centuries, it caught up with Ghana in 1950 and subsequently diverged
considerably, becoming almost twice as wealthy as Ghana by 1970. Throughout
the 1970s, the Liberian economy stagnated.

In 1926, the Liberian government gave the Firestone Tire company the right to
lease up to 1 million acres of land for 99 years at a cost of 6 cents per
acre. Firestone developed an inordinate sway over the Liberian government,
effectively acquiring control over its finances in the subsequent period. The
company was an important source of foreign investment into Liberia during this
period. Firestone then set about establishing rubber tree plantations of the
non-native South American rubber tree, _Hevea brasiliensis_ in the country. By
the 1950s, the company was Liberia's largest private employer and also its
largest exporter. Vincent Browne wrote in 1955 that rubber accounted for more
than $45,000,000 of Liberia's approximately $55,000,000 worth of exports.
Liberia became one of the largest rubber exporters in the world in the post-
World War II period. Today, Firestone's rubber plantation in Liberia is the
world's largest contiguous rubber plantation, operated by the Firestone (now
Bridgestone) subsidiary, the Firestone Natural Rubber Company.

In the 1940s, Liberia become one of the largest recipients of American aid. US
aid to Liberia began with the Lend-Lease program of 1942. The aid per capita
received by Liberia was comparable to that obtained by countries such as Korea
and Marshall Aid recipients like the United Kingdom. Economic historian George
Dalton estimated in 1965 that Liberia received more aid per capita from the
United States than any other African country.

In the post-WWII period, Liberia tried to become a destination for offshore
services, as the country loosened laws related to ship registration,
corporation, and taxes. The Liberian shipping registry was highly successful
as Liberia had by the 1960s become the largest ship registry in the world in
terms of tonnage.

The Liberian economy had relied heavily on the mining of iron ore prior to the
civil war. Liberia was a major exporter of iron ore on the world market. By
the 1970s, iron mining accounted for more than half of Liberia's export
earnings. Since the coup d'état of 1980, the country's economic growth rate
has slowed down because of a decline in the demand for iron ore on the world
market and political upheavals in Liberia.

Upon the end of the war in 2003, GDP growth began to accelerate again,
reaching a peak of 9.4% in 2007. In 2009, during the Great Recession GDP
growth slowed to 4.6%, though a strengthening agricultural sector led by
rubber and timber exports increased growth to 5.1% in 2010 and an expected
7.3% in 2011, making the economy one of the 20 fastest growing in the world.

In March 2010, Bob Johnson, founder of BET, funded the first hotel constructed
in Liberia in 20 years. The 13-acre (53,000 m2) luxury resort was built in the
Paynesville section of Monrovia.

Liberia's external debt was estimated in 2006 at approximately $4.5 billion,
800% of GDP. As a result of bilateral, multilateral and commercial debt relief
from 2007 to 2010, the country's external debt fell to $222.9 million by 2011.
openai_summarised_points: • Independent Liberia's economic history suffers from limited archival documentation, complicating comprehensive assessments by economic historians; the Liberian government only began producing GDP per capita data in 1964.

• A 2022 study by LSE economic historian Leigh A. Gardner estimated Liberia's GDP per capita at $430 in 1845, which was just above subsistence level and approximately half of Japan's GDP per capita at that time.
• Liberia's GDP per capita rose to approximately $500 by the time of independence (circa 1847), but the economy stagnated until the 1930s, when a period of rapid economic growth commenced.

• During the 19th and early 20th centuries, Liberia was poorer than Ghana; however, by 1950 Liberia had caught up with Ghana and subsequently diverged, becoming almost twice as wealthy as Ghana by 1970.
• The Liberian economy stagnated throughout the 1970s after the period of growth in the mid-20th century.
• In 1926, the Liberian government granted the Firestone Tire Company the right to lease up to 1 million acres of land for 99 years at a cost of 6 cents per acre.
• Firestone developed significant influence over the Liberian government, effectively gaining control over its finances during this period, and became a major source of foreign investment in Liberia.
• Firestone established rubber tree plantations in Liberia using the non-native South American rubber tree species, _Hevea brasiliensis_.

• By the 1950s, Firestone was Liberia's largest private employer and largest exporter; in 1955, Vincent Browne reported that rubber accounted for over $45,000,000 of Liberia's approximately $55,000,000 worth of exports.

• Post-World War II, Liberia became one of the world's largest rubber exporters; today, Firestone's rubber plantation in Liberia is the world's largest contiguous rubber plantation, operated by the Firestone Natural Rubber Company, a subsidiary of Bridgestone.
• In the 1940s, Liberia became one of the largest recipients of American aid, beginning with the 1942 Lend-Lease program.
• The per capita aid received by Liberia was comparable to that received by countries such as Korea and Marshall Aid recipients like the United Kingdom.
• Economic historian George Dalton estimated in 1965 that Liberia received more U.S. aid per capita than any other African country.
• After World War II, Liberia sought to become a destination for offshore services by loosening laws related to ship registration, corporations, and taxes.
• By the 1960s, Liberia had become the largest ship registry in the world in terms of tonnage, reflecting the success of its shipping registry.
• Prior to the civil war, Liberia's economy heavily relied on iron ore mining; by the 1970s, iron mining accounted for more than half of Liberia's export earnings.
• Since the 1980 coup d'état, Liberia's economic growth slowed due to a decline in global demand for iron ore and political upheavals within the country.
• Following the end of the civil war in 2003, Liberia's GDP growth accelerated, peaking at 9.4% in 2007.

• During the Great Recession in 2009, GDP growth slowed to 4.6%, but a strengthening agricultural sector led by rubber and timber exports increased growth to 5.1% in 2010 and an expected 7.3% in 2011, positioning Liberia among the 20 fastest-growing economies globally.

• In March 2010, Bob Johnson, founder of BET, funded the construction of the first hotel built in Liberia in 20 years; the 13-acre (53,000 m²) luxury resort was established in the Paynesville section of Monrovia.
• Liberia's external debt was estimated at approximately $4.5 billion in 2006, equating to 800% of GDP.
• Due to bilateral, multilateral, and commercial debt relief efforts from 2007 to 2010, Liberia's external debt was reduced to $222.9 million by 2011.

Liberia's business sector is largely controlled by foreigners mainly of
Levantine (primarily Lebanese) and Indian descent. There also are limited
numbers of Chinese people engaged in agriculture. The largest timber
concession, Oriental Timber Corporation (OTC), is Indonesian owned. There also
are significant numbers of West Africais engaged in cross-border trade. Legal
monopolies are possible; for example, Cemenco holds a monopoly on cement
production.
openai_summarised_points: • Liberia's business sector is predominantly controlled by foreigners, primarily individuals of Levantine descent, with a significant proportion being Lebanese.
• Indian nationals also constitute a notable segment of the foreign business community in Liberia.
• A limited number of Chinese individuals are involved in agricultural activities within Liberia.
• The largest timber concession in Liberia, the Oriental Timber Corporation (OTC), is owned by Indonesian interests.
• There is a considerable presence of West African traders engaged in cross-border commerce within Liberia.
• Certain industries in Liberia operate under legal monopolies; for instance, Cemenco holds an exclusive monopoly on cement production in the country.

Timber and rubber are Liberia's main export items since the end of the war.
Liberia earns more than $100 million and more than $70 million annually from
timber and rubber exports, respectively.
openai_summarised_points: • Since the end of the war, timber and rubber have constituted Liberia's primary export commodities.
• Liberia generates annual revenues exceeding $100 million from timber exports.
• Rubber exports contribute more than $70 million annually to Liberia's economy.

Alluvial diamond and gold mining activities also account for some economic
activity. In recent years (2005 - 2012), foreign investment from ArcelorMittal
Steel, BHP Biliton, and China Union is aiding the revitalization of the iron-
ore mining sector.

Liberia has begun exploration for offshore oil; unproven oil reserves may be
in excess of one billion barrels. The government divided its offshore waters
into 17 blocks and began auctioning off exploration licenses for the blocks in
2004, with further auctions in 2007 and 2009. An additional 13 ultra-deep
offshore blocks were demarcated in 2011 and planned for auction. Among the
companies to have won licenses are Repsol YPF, Chevron Corporation, and
Woodside Petroleum.
openai_summarised_points: • Alluvial diamond and gold mining contribute to Liberia’s economic activity, representing a significant sector within the country’s mining industry.

• Between 2005 and 2012, foreign investment from major international companies such as ArcelorMittal Steel, BHP Billiton, and China Union has played a crucial role in revitalizing Liberia’s iron-ore mining sector.
• Liberia has initiated exploration efforts for offshore oil reserves, with unproven reserves estimated to potentially exceed one billion barrels.
• The Liberian government divided its offshore waters into 17 blocks and commenced auctioning exploration licenses for these blocks in 2004, followed by additional auctions in 2007 and 2009.
• In 2011, Liberia demarcated an additional 13 ultra-deep offshore blocks, which were planned to be auctioned to attract further exploration and investment.
• Prominent international oil companies that have secured exploration licenses in Liberia’s offshore blocks include Repsol YPF, Chevron Corporation, and Woodside Petroleum.

Liberia maintains an open maritime registry, meaning that owners of ships can
register their vessels as Liberian with relatively few restrictions. This has
meant that Liberian ship registration is usually understood as the employment
of a flag of convenience. Liberia has the second-largest maritime registry in
the world behind Panama, with 4,300 vessels registered under its flag
accounting for 12% of ships worldwide. This includes 35% of the world's tanker
fleet. Liberia earned more than $18 million from its maritime program in 2000.
openai_summarised_points: • Liberia operates an open maritime registry system, allowing ship owners to register their vessels under the Liberian flag with relatively few restrictions.
• The practice of registering ships under Liberia’s flag is commonly recognized as employing a flag of convenience.
• Liberia holds the position of having the second-largest maritime registry globally, surpassed only by Panama.
• As of the data provided, there are 4,300 vessels registered under the Liberian flag.
• Ships registered in Liberia constitute approximately 12% of the total number of ships worldwide.
• Notably, 35% of the world’s tanker fleet is registered under the Liberian flag.
• In the year 2000, Liberia’s maritime program generated revenue exceeding $18 million.

text:
Liberia has relied heavily on vast amounts of foreign assistance, particularly
from the United States, Sweden, Britain, France, Italy, Germany, the People's
Republic of China, and Romania. But because of the Liberian Government's
perceived disregard for human rights, foreign assistance to Liberia has
declined drastically.

The Republic of China (Taiwan) and Libya are currently the largest donors of
direct financial aid to the Liberian Government. Significant amounts of aid
continue to come in from Western countries through international aid agencies
and non-governmental organizations, avoiding direct aid to the government.
openai_summarised_points: • Liberia has historically depended extensively on substantial foreign assistance from multiple countries, including the United States, Sweden, Britain, France, Italy, Germany, the People's Republic of China, and Romania.
• Foreign aid to Liberia has experienced a significant decline due to the Liberian Government's perceived disregard for human rights, which has negatively impacted donor willingness.
• Currently, the Republic of China (Taiwan) and Libya stand as the largest direct financial aid donors to the Liberian Government.

• Despite reductions in direct government aid, considerable amounts of foreign assistance continue to flow into Liberia from Western countries through international aid agencies and non-governmental organizations, thereby circumventing direct government channels.

text:
Communications in Liberia is the press, radio, television, fixed and mobile
telephones, and the Internet. There are six major newspapers in Liberia, and
45% of the population has a mobile phone service. Also, the radio stations in
Liberia are abundant to the extent that there are over 70 radio stations in
the entire country (Liberia). As for Montserrado County, there exist about 30
radio stations.

Even as it struggles with economic and political constraints, Liberia's media
environment is expanding. The number of registered newspapers and radio
stations (many of them community stations) is on the rise despite limited
market potential. And politically critical content and investigative pieces do
get published or broadcast.
openai_summarised_points: • Communications in Liberia encompass the press, radio, television, fixed and mobile telephones, and the Internet.
• Liberia has six major newspapers serving its population.
• Approximately 45% of Liberia's population has access to mobile phone services.
• The country hosts over 70 radio stations nationwide, indicating a high density of radio broadcasting.
• Montserrado County alone contains about 30 radio stations, reflecting a concentration of media outlets in this region.
• Despite ongoing economic and political challenges, Liberia's media environment is experiencing growth and expansion.
• The number of registered newspapers and radio stations, including many community-based stations, is increasing despite limited market potential.
• Liberia's media outlets publish and broadcast politically critical content and investigative journalism, demonstrating a degree of press freedom and critical engagement.

Formal electricity services are solely provided by the state-owned Liberia
Electricity Corporation, which operates a small grid almost exclusively in the
Greater Monrovia District. The vast majority of electric energy services is
provided by small privately owned generators. At $0.54 per kWh, the
electricity tariff in Liberia is among the highest in the world. Total
installed capacity in 2013 was 20 MW, a sharp decline from a peak of 191 MW in
1989.
openai_summarised_points: • Formal electricity services in Liberia are exclusively provided by the state-owned Liberia Electricity Corporation, which operates a limited grid primarily within the Greater Monrovia District.
• The majority of electric energy services outside the formal grid are supplied by small, privately owned generators.
• As of the data provided, the electricity tariff in Liberia stands at $0.54 per kilowatt-hour (kWh), positioning it among the highest electricity prices globally.
• Liberia’s total installed electricity generation capacity was 20 megawatts (MW) in 2013, representing a significant reduction from its historical peak capacity of 191 MW recorded in 1989.

text:
Liberia is a member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS).
With Guinea and Sierra Leone, it formed the Mano River Union (MRU) for
development and the promotion of regional economic integration. The MRU became
all but defunct because of the Liberian civil war which spilled over into
neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea.
